awd_titl_txt: Biochemical and Molecular Engineering XIX Conference; Puerto Vallarta, Mexico; July 12-16, 2015
awd_abstract_narration:
1540505
Korpics, Kevin M.

This proposal seeks support from the National Science Foundation for the 19th International Conference on Biochemical and Molecular Engineering (BME XIX) to be held in Puerto Vallarta, Mexico, July 12-16, 2015. The theme of the BME XIX conference is Engineering Next Generation Solutions, and it will be organized under the auspices of the Engineering Conferences International (ECI), a not-for-profit global engineering conferences program.

The focus of the conference will be on research at the cutting-edge of biotechnology including synthetic biology, biomolecular design, the nano-bio interface, biofuels, metabolic engineering, biomolecular networks, and stem cell differentiation in combination with core areas of Biochemical Engineering. In addition, workshops  will address how the biochemical engineering community can develop technologies that respond to global threats like Ebola, and how Biochemical Engineering Education might change in the future  in response to the needs of industry for a workforce trained in specific areas.

The conference is co-sponsered by the Biotechnology and Biochemical Engineering Program of the CBET Division and by the Synthetic and Systems Biology Program of the Division of Molecular and Cellular Biology.
org_div_long_name: Division of Chemical, Bioengineering, Environmental, and Transport Systems

por.por_cntn:
The Biochemical and Molecular Engineering XIX conference was held successfully from July 12-16, 2015 at the Hyatt Ziva in Puerto Vallarta, Mexico.

The conference contributed to the enhancement and improvement of scientific, engineering and/or educational activities by bringing together leaders from academia and industry along with young people in the field of biochemical engineering. In addition, this meeting provided the foundation for collaborations between researchers. The meeting conveners will be guest editors of a special issue of the Biochemical Engineering Journal to disseminate results.  Specific workshops were held that addressed needs in education and training.  

The meeting brought together 158 attendees from throughout the world. Attendees were from the following countries:

United Kingdom

2%

USA

122

77%

Grand Total

158

100%

About half the attendees were from academia and 22 graduate students (about 14%) attended. The remaining attendees were from industry (34%) and government/other (3%).

Twelve technical sessions were held as well as two poster sessions and three concurrent workshops. Workshops were held to address training and professional development.

Funding from NSF was a key to the success of the conference by supporting the attendance of academic speakers and graduate students who otherwise would have been unable to attend.

 


Last Modified: 01/04/2016
Modified by: Kevin M Korpics
